marketNews.title: Nickel Prices Break US$19,000/Ton, Highest in 2024
marketNews.content:
The three-month nickel futures on the London Metal Exchange rose 4.1 % on Friday (19 April) to US$19,326 per metric ton, marking the highest level in 2024 and the first time the price breached US$19,000 per ton since September 2023. Nickel has strengthened 8.6 % week-over-week last week, with a cumulative increase of 16.4 % year-to-date as of 22 April 2024.

Several factors are believed to be driving the recent nickel price surge, including:

- The United States and United Kingdom have imposed bans on trading nickel products originating from Russia. Under this rule, Russian nickel can no longer be traded on the LME or the Chicago Mercantile Exchange (CME). Russia accounts for about 6 % of global refined nickel production.
- Delays in the approval of mining permits (RKAB) for nickel in Indonesia, which could reduce supply. Indonesia has extended the validity of RKABs from one year to three years, causing longer processing times for permit approvals.
- Market rumours that Chinese authorities plan to purchase up to 200 000 tonnes of nickel pig iron (NPI).

The price rally occurs while many market participants still expect nickel to remain at relatively low levels. In April 2024, ING commodities analyst Ewa Manthey predicted that nickel prices would stay under pressure in the short term due to a gloomy macro-economic outlook and continued global oversupply driven by increased Indonesian production. Bloomberg’s consensus forecast projects the average nickel price to be US$17.048 per tonne in 2024. Since the start of the year, the average price has been US$16.853 per tonne up to 22 April 2024.

marketNews.title: Rupiah Weakens to 16,000 per USD, Raising Expectations of BI Rate Hike
marketNews.content: The Indonesian rupiah weakened to the 16,000 per US$ level last week, marking the lowest exchange rate since April 2020. This depreciation has heightened expectations that Bank Indonesia may raise the BI Rate. Seven out of 22 economists surveyed by Bloomberg predict a 25-basis-point increase in the BI Rate, while the remaining respondents expect the rate to remain at 6 %. In a separate survey compiled by Reuters, economists anticipate that Bank Indonesia will keep the BI Rate at 6 % during the Governor’s Board meeting on 23-24 April 2024. Reuters’ consensus also expects the central bank to begin cutting rates from the second quarter of 2024, moving to the third quarter, as the Fed adopts a more hawkish stance.

marketNews.title: Constitutional Court Rejects Election Re-run Lawsuits
marketNews.content: The Constitutional Court on Monday (22 April) dismissed all lawsuits filed by the Anies-Muhaimin and Ganjar-Mahfud teams seeking a repeat election and disqualification of the Prabowo-Gibran ticket. The Court ruled that there was no evidence of systematic fraud or presidential interference, and no state agencies, regional officials, or social assistance programs were mobilised to influence the 2024 election.

marketNews.title: Indonesia’s Trade Surplus Expands to $4.47 B in March 2024
marketNews.content: The Central Statistics Agency (BPS) reported that Indonesia’s trade surplus increased to $4.47 billion in March 2024 (versus $2.83 billion in March 2023). This result exceeded the consensus estimate of $1.23 billion and marked the largest surplus since February 2023. The surplus was driven by a more moderate decline in exports (-4.19 % YoY) compared with a sharper drop in imports (-12.76 % YoY). Over the first quarter of 2024, Indonesia posted a trade surplus of $7.31 billion (versus $12.11 billion in Q1 2023), with exports down 7.25 % and imports down 0.10 %.

marketNews.title: Government Draft Work Plan 2025 Targets Tax Ratio of 11.2-12 % of GDP
marketNews.content: Kontan reported that the draft 2025 Government Work Plan (RKP) aims for a tax-to-GDP ratio of 11.2-12 % in 2025, up from the realized ratios of 10.4 % in 2022 and 10.32 % in 2023. To achieve this target, the government is said to plan the establishment of a State Revenue Agency and to strengthen tax extension and supervision of high-net-worth taxpayers. The RKP serves as the basis for the 2025 state budget.

marketNews.title: Sugar Stock Dwindles as Prices Rise 25.3 % YoY
marketNews.content: Bisnis and Kontan reported that raw sugar stocks are depleting as the price rose 25.3 % YoY to IDR 18,050 per kilogram on 20 April 2024. Yadi Yusriadi of the Indonesian Sugar Association explained that the shortage is due to delayed sugar imports and the upcoming sugarcane crushing season, which is expected to start in May 2024. The Ministry of Trade’s Domestic Trade Director General, Isy Karim, said national raw sugar stocks stand at 330,000 tonnes, sufficient for 1.5-2 months.

tickerNews.title: ACES Reports Same-Store Sales Growth of +19.9 % YoY in March 2024
tickerNews.content: Ace Hardware Indonesia recorded same-store sales growth (SSSG) of +19.9 % YoY in March 2024 (vs Feb 2024: +15.3 % YoY, Mar 2023: +1.2 % YoY), with indicative sales of IDR 710 billion. SSSG in March 2024 occurred across all regions: Jakarta (+13.5 %), Java outside Jakarta (+20.3 %), and outside Java (+23.3 %). Over the 3-month period 2024, ACES posted SSSG of +13.2 % YoY, with indicative sales of approximately IDR 1.98 trillion. Management targets SSSG growth of +7 % YoY for 2024.

tickerNews.title: MEDC Divests Ophir Vietnam Block 12W and Plans Share Buyback
tickerNews.content: Medco Energi International announced that it has divested its entire shareholding in Ophir Vietnam Block 12W B.V. to Bitexco Energy Company Limited for an undisclosed amount. CEO Roberto Lorato said the divestment aligns with MEDC’s strategy to actively manage its portfolio through targeted acquisitions and divestments. Additionally, MEDC plans a share buyback of up to 100 million (0.4 %) shares with funds up to IDR 200 billion, implying a maximum buyback price of IDR 2,000 per share. The plan will be discussed at the AGM on 30 May 2024.

tickerNews.title: BRIS Prepares to Divest Up to 20 % of Bank Syariah Indonesia Shares
tickerNews.content: State-owned Enterprises Minister Erick Thohir said the ministry is ready to divest up to 20 % of Bank Syariah Indonesia shares to strategic investors, aiming to strengthen BRIS liquidity. The shares to be offered will come from the holdings of Bank Negara Indonesia (BBNI) and Bank Rakyat Indonesia (BBRI). Erick said roadshows have been held in Qatar and Europe to meet potential strategic investors for BRIS. Previously, Reuters reported that Abu Dhabi Islamic Bank is considering acquiring 15 % of BRIS from BBRI for a value of $1.1 billion (~IDR 17.8 trillion).

tickerNews.title: SMRA Reports Strong Marketing Sales Growth in Q1 2024
tickerNews.content: Summarecon Agung recorded marketing sales of IDR 424 billion (+167 % MoM, +15.6 % YoY) in March 2024. In Q1 2024, marketing sales reached IDR 809 billion (+23.6 % YoY), equal to 16.2 % of the 2024 target of IDR 5 trillion. The achievement outperformed Q1 2023, which met only 13.1 % of the 2023 target of IDR 5 trillion. The residential segment still dominated marketing sales with an 84 % contribution, followed by apartments (7 %), land parcels (7 %) and shophouses (3 %).

tickerNews.title: BBYB Plans Rights Issue of Up to 5 Billion New Shares
tickerNews.content: Bank Neo Commerce plans to conduct a rights issue of up to 5 billion new shares with a ratio of 100,000,000:41,532,324 and a dilution effect of up to 29.34 %. The issue price has not been announced; the funds will be used to strengthen capital structure and working capital to finance credit expansion and other productive assets. Controlling shareholder PT Akulaku Silvrr Indonesia and shareholders holding more than 5 % (including PT Rockcore Financial Technology Co.Ltd) will exercise their rights. The rights are cum-right in the regular market and will be negotiated on 20 June 2024.

tickerNews.title: SMGR Proposes Dividend Payout Ratio of 25-30 % for FY 2023
tickerNews.content: In an analyst meeting on Monday (22 April), Semen Indonesia management indicated that it plans to propose a dividend payout ratio of around 25-30 % for fiscal year 2023, lower than the historical average of 46 % in 2018-2022 and below the management guidance of 80 % at the start of the year. This implies a dividend of approximately IDR 80.4-96.4 per share, or a dividend yield of 1.6-1.9 % based on the SMGR share price of IDR 5,025 on Monday (22 April). Management explained that the lower payout ratio is intended to temporarily increase cash levels to mitigate global uncertainty due to geopolitical conflicts.
